com.googlecode.streamflyer.regex
Class RegexModifier

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.streamflyer.regex.RegexModifier
All Implemented Interfaces:
Modifier
public class RegexModifier
extends Object
implements Modifier

Finds text that matches a given regular expression. The match is processed by the given MatchProcessor. The default match processor replaces the matched texts with the configured replacements.

Contents

1. How do I use this modifier?
2. Instead of replacing text I want to do something else when the regular expression matches. How can I do this?
3. How can I find out the position of the matches within the stream?
4. How much memory does the modifier consume?
5. Which features of Java's Pattern are not supported yet?
6. Which features of Java's Matcher are not supported yet?
7. How do I configure RegexModifier if my pattern contains ^ or \b or \B?
8. What value to choose for the constructor parameter minimumLengthOfLookBehind?
9. What value to choose for the constructor parameter newNumberOfChars?

1. How do I use this modifier?

EXAMPLE: 

// choose the character stream to modify
Reader originalReader = new StringReader("edit stream");

// define the regular expression and the replacement
Modifier myModifier = new RegexModifier("edit stream", 0, "modify stream");

// create the modifying reader that wraps the original reader
Reader modifyingReader = new ModifyingReader(originalReader, myModifier);

// use the modifying reader instead of the original reader
String output = IOUtils.toString(modifyingReader);
assertEquals("modify stream", output);

2. Instead of replacing text I want to do something else when the regular expression matches. How can I do this?

Implement your own MatchProcessor. In the following example the processor prints the matched text on the console.

EXAMPLE: 

class MatchPrinter implements MatchProcessor {

    public MatchProcessorResult process(StringBuilder characterBuffer,
            int firstModifiableCharacterInBuffer, MatchResult matchResult) {

        // print the matches text
        System.out.println("match: " + matchResult.group());

        // continue matching behind the end of the matched text
        return new MatchProcessorResult(matchResult.end(), true);
    }
}
// ...
Modifier myModifier = new RegexModifier("^.*ERROR.*$", Pattern.MULTILINE, new MatchPrinter(), 0, 2048);

3. How can I find out the position of the matches within the stream?

You must count the characters that you skip. You can do this by subclassing RegexModifier and overwrite Modifier.modify(StringBuilder, int, boolean).

You might find LineColumnAwareModificationFactory and PositionAwareModificationFactory helpful as well.

4. How much memory does the modifier consume?

The maximum buffer size used by this modifier does not exceed the size of the longest match by factor three. EXAMPLE: Assume in your stream the longest match contains 100K characters. Then the internally used buffer is at no time larger than 300K characters. But this rule does not apply if you use greedy operators. If you use greedy operators, the entire stream content might be loaded into the memory at once. The web page of this project gives more details.

5. Which features of Java's Pattern are not supported yet?

Apart from \G (the boundary matcher that matches the end of the previous match) all other features mentioned in Pattern are supported.

6. Which features of Java's Matcher are not supported yet?

Java's Matcher allows the user to change the used pattern. RegexModifier does not enables this out-of-the-box. To implement this feature you must subclass an existing OnStreamMatcher implementation and connect it to your MatchProcessor.

Features that are region-related (like anchoring bounds, transparent bounds) and features that determine how to continue the matching are not configurable because they are already setup in an appropriate way by the RegexModifier.

7. How do I configure RegexModifier if my pattern contains ^ or \b or \B?

These pattern constructs require a look-behind. Therefore, set minimumLengthOfLookBehind at least to one.

8. What value to choose for the constructor parameter minimumLengthOfLookBehind?

If your pattern does not contain zero-width look-behind constructs, then you can choose any value. Zero is recommended.

Choose one if your pattern contains zero-width look-behind constructs like ^ or \b or \B but not constructs like (?<=X) or (?<!X).

If your pattern contains zero-width look-behind constructs like (?<=X) or (?<!X), you have to find out how many characters the matcher needs at least to match properly by looking behind. Use this number as value for minimumLengthOfLookBehind. EXAMPLE: Let's say your pattern might check for (?<=a{3}) and (?<=b{5}) in front of the actual match. Then the appropriate value is five. If you set the value to a lower value, then there is no guarantee that the modifier matches properly.

9. What value to choose for the constructor parameter newNumberOfChars?

This value determines how many characters are usually processed at once. If the value is too high or too low, the performance decreases. The optimal value depends on the length and number of matches in the stream.

18.06.2011

rwoo

factory

matchProcessor

protected MatchProcessor matchProcessor

matcher

protected OnStreamMatcher matcher
The compiled representation of a regular expression. If the regular expression matches, then a modification shall be carried out.

newNumberOfChars

protected int newNumberOfChars

unseenCharactersToSkip

private int unseenCharactersToSkip
The number of characters that shall be skipped automatically if the modifier is called the next time.

This property is either zero or one (not greater). If this property is one, then the modifier tries to match behind the first modifiable character. If this property is zero, then the modifier tries to match before the first modifiable character.

RegexModifier

public RegexModifier(String regex,
                     int flags,
                     String replacement,
                     int minimumLengthOfLookBehind,
                     int newNumberOfChars)
Creates a modifier that matches a regular expression on character streams and replaces the matches.

This modifier uses OnStreamStandardMatcher which is not the fastest implementation of OnStreamMatcher. If you want to use a faster matcher, use RegexModifier(OnStreamMatcher, MatchProcessor, int, int) instead.

A more convenient use of a RegexModifier is provided by the ModifyingReaderFactory respectively ModifyingWriterFactory.

Parameters:
regex - the regular expression that describe the text that shall be replaced. See Pattern.compile(String, int).
flags - the flags that are to use when the regex is applied on the character stream. See Pattern.compile(String, int).
replacement - the replacement for the text that is matched via regex. See Matcher.appendReplacement(StringBuffer, String).
minimumLengthOfLookBehind - See RegexModifier(OnStreamMatcher, MatchProcessor, int, int) .
newNumberOfChars - See RegexModifier(OnStreamMatcher, MatchProcessor, int, int) .

RegexModifier

public RegexModifier(String regex,
                     int flags,
                     MatchProcessor matchProcessor,
                     int minimumLengthOfLookBehind,
                     int newNumberOfChars)
See RegexModifier(String, int, String, int, int).

RegexModifier

public RegexModifier(OnStreamMatcher matcher,
                     MatchProcessor matchProcessor,
                     int minimumLengthOfLookBehind,
                     int newNumberOfChars)
Creates a modifier that matches a regular expression on character streams and does 'something' if matches are found.

Parameters:
matcher - Matches a regular expression on a CharSequence.
matchProcessor - Defines what to do if the regular expression matches some text in the stream.
minimumLengthOfLookBehind - See AfterModification.getNewMinimumLengthOfLookBehind().
newNumberOfChars - See AfterModification.getNewNumberOfChars(). This should not be smaller than the length of the characters sequence the #pattern needs to match properly. In case you want to match more than once, the value should be higher.

modify

public AfterModification modify(StringBuilder characterBuffer,
                                int firstModifiableCharacterInBuffer,
                                boolean endOfStreamHit)
Description copied from interface: Modifier
Processes the characters in the given character buffer, i.e. deletes or replaces or inserts characters, or keeps the characters as they are.

Specified by:
modify in interface Modifier
Parameters:
characterBuffer - The next characters provided from the modifiable stream. It contains the modifiable characters, (optionally) preceded by unmodifiable characters.

The modifier can modify the content of the buffer as appropriate the modifier must not modify the unmodifiable characters, i.e. the characters before position firstModifiableCharacterInBufferIndex must not be modified.

Your modifier should manage the capacity of the buffer on its own - as the optimal management of the capacity depends on the specific purpose of the modifier.

The given buffer must be never null.

firstModifiableCharacterInBuffer - index of the first modifiable character in the buffer. The index of the first character in the buffer is zero. If there is not modifiable character in the buffer, then this value is equal the length of the buffer.
endOfStreamHit - True if no more characters can be read from the stream, i.e. the character buffer contains the all the characters up to the end of the stream.
Returns:
Returns an object that defines how ModifyingReader or ModifyingWriter shall behave before calling Modifier.modify(StringBuilder, int, boolean) again.
See Also:
Modifier.modify(java.lang.StringBuilder, int, boolean)

__checkpoint

protected boolean __checkpoint(Object... checkpointDescription)
This method is called if a certain line of code is reached ("checkpoint").

This method should be called only if the modifier is tested. Otherwise you might experience performance penalties.

Parameters:
checkpointDescription - A list of objects describing the checkpoint. The objects should be given as name-value-pairs.
Returns:
Returns true. This allows you to use this method as side-effect in Java assertions.
